sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a GNOME2 frontend for Gnu Privacy Guard. &app; provides the following components:

&app; is an application and a project. The primary goal of the &app; application is to provide an easy to use yet powerful key management tool. The secondary goal is to provide basic encryption capabilities. The goal of the project is to provide the &app; application, along with plugins for GNOME applications to make encryption easy on the GNOME Desktop.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Other GPG Keys Manager .
Run &app; from the command line.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the Key Manager is displayed.
The Key Manager window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menubar contains commands for accessing the various dialogs and windows.
The toolbar only contains commands that affect keys.

The key list shows the keys in your key ring. Some keys also have sub keys. Each key and sub key show the following attributes:
Name
Key ID
Trust
Type
Length
Only one key may be selected at a time.
The statusbar shows operation status messages. Operations are either successful or fail.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: You can use the &app; application to access the following features:
Any window with a menubar contains a View menu. In the View menu, you may choose whether or not to view the Toolbar or Statusbar. Selecting either option will hide or show the selected component.
Any window with a statusbar will display status messages from operations. The current or last focused statusbar can also display operation progress.
You can get help for a feature by clicking help in a dialog or selecting Help.
sect1.warning: While &app; is in use, do not make any changes to the key ring with another program. External changes could have unkown and possibly undesirable affects.

sect2.title: Generating a Key
sect2.para:
To generate a new key, choose FileNew from the Key Manager. The Generate Key dialog is displayed.
Generate Key Dialog
You will need to enter your full name, a valid email address, and a comment describing the key. This will create the primary user ID. You will then need to choose a key type and a key length. The range of the length depends on the type selected. Then you must choose a key expiration date, or have the key never expire. When finished, click OK.
sect2.warning: No other operations should be performed during key generation. Doing so will stop the generation process prematurely.

sect2.title: Importing Keys
sect2.para:
To import keys, choose FileOpen... from the Key Manager. The Import Keys dialog is displayed.
Import Dialog
Import from a file
To import keys from a file, select Import from File, choose a file, then click OK.
Import from text
To import keys from text, select Import from Text, paste the text into the text area, then click OK. The text must be ascii armored in order to be imported successfully.

sect2.title: Exporting a Key
sect2.para:
To export a key from the Key Manager, select a key from the list and then choose FileSave As... or click Save As. You can do the same from the of the key you want to export. The Export Key dialog is displayed.
Export Dialog
Export to File
To export a key to a file, select Export to File, choose the filename, then click OK.
Export to Text
To export a key to text, select Export to Text, then click OK. The exported key will be in the text area. If is not enabled, exported text will not display properly.

sect2.title: Text Editor
sect2.para:
To use the text editor, choose FileText Editor from the Key Manager.
&app; Text Editor
should be enabled while using the Text Editor. Otherwise, text will not be displayed properly, rendering the Text Editor useless. The following operations are available for text:
Import
Select EditImport, click Import, or right-click and select Import. This will import any keys contained in the text.
Export
Select EditExport. The dialog will appear, in which you can select keys to export. When finished, the chosen keys will be exported to the text.
Sign
Select EditSign, click Sign, or right-click and select Sign. After confirming the to the , the text will be signed.
Clear Sign
Select EditClear Sign, click Clear Sign, or right-click and select Clear Sign. After confirming the to the , the text will be clear signed.
Encrypt
Select EditEncrypt, click Encrypt, or right-click and select Encrypt. The dialog will appear, in which you can select the keys to encrypt to. When finished, the text will be encrypted to the selected keys.
Decrypt
You must have access to the secret key of one of the encryption keys in your key ring in order to decrypt the text.
Select EditDecrypt, click Decrypt, or right-click and select Decrypt and enter the . If successful, the text will be decrypted.
Verify
You must have the signing key in your key ring in order to successfully verify a signature.
Select EditVerify, click Verify, or right-click and select Verify. If successful, the dialog will appear. Otherwise, you will receive an error regarding how verification failed.
Decrypt and Verify
Decrypt and Verify combines the decrypt and verify operations by decrypting, then verifying the text. To decrypt and verify, select EditDecrypt and Verify or right-click and select Decrypt and Verify.

sect2.title: File Manager
sect2.para:
To use the File Manager, choose FileFile Manager from the Key Manager.
&app; File Manager
The following operations are available for files:
Import
Choose an existing file, then select EditImport, or click Import. Any keys in the file will be added to the key ring.
Export
Enter a filename (the file does not have to exist), then select EditExport. The dialog will appear, in which you can select the keys to export. When finished, the exported keys will be appended to the file.
Sign
Choose an existing file to sign, then select EditSign, or click Sign. After confirming the to the , a detached signature file will be created with the same file name, but with a .asc or .sig extension, depending on whether is enabled.
Encrypt
Choose an existing file to encrypt, then select EditEncrypt, or click Encrypt. The dialog will appear, in which you can select the keys to encrypt to. When finished, a new, encrypted, file will be created with the same name, but with a .asc or .gpg extension, depending on whether is enabled.
Decrypt
You must have access to the secret key of one of the encryption keys in your key ring in order to decrypt a file.
Choose an encrypted file to decrypt. The filename must have a .asc or .gpg extension. After choosing the file, select EditDecrypt, or click Decrypt and enter the . If successful, a decrypted file will be created with the same name, but without the extension.
Verify
You must have the signing key in your key ring in order to successfully verify a signature.
Choose a detached signature file to verify. The signature file must have a .asc or .sig extension, and it must have the same name as the signed file, but without the extension.
Choosing a Detached Signature File
Select foo.sig or foo.asc, where the signed file foo is in the same directory.
After choosing the file, select EditVerify, or click Verify. If success, the dialog will appear, otherwise you will get an error message regarding how verification failed.
Decrypt and Verify
Decrypt and verify combines the decrypt and verify operations by decrypting the file, then verifying and signatures found. To decrypt and verify, choose an encrypted file then select EditDecrypt and Verify.

sect2.title: Key Properties
sect2.para: To view key properties, select a key from the list and choose EditProperties, click Properties, or double-click the key. The Key Properties window is displayed.
The Key Properties window initially shows the key's

listitem.para: Fingerprint,
Owner Trust,
Key Attributes, and

sect3.title: Disable Key
sect3.para: You can disable a key by checking Disabled. A disabled key cannot be used for encryption. Most keys should be left enabled.

sect3.title: Change Owner Trust
sect3.para: You can change the owner trust of a key by using the Owner Trust option menu.

sect3.title: Change Expiration Date
sect3.para: If the key has a secret key, then you can change the expiration date. If Never Expires is checked, then the key will never expire. Otherwise, the date shown will be the expiration date.
sect3.note: Changing the expiration date requires a .

sect3.title: User ID Properties
sect3.para: User IDs are shown below the primary key attributes. If the key has a secret key and there is more than one User ID, then you can:

sect3.title: Subkey Properties
sect3.para: Subkeys are hidden by default. To show them, select ViewSubkeys. If the key has subkeys, they will be shown below the .
Each subkey shows its attributes and Status. The Status can be:

listitem.para: Good,
Revoked, or
Expired,

sect3.para: depending on the state of the subkey. If the key has a secret key, then you can:

sect4.title: Change Subkey Expiration Date
sect4.para: As with the for the primary key, a subkey's expiration date can be changed if the key has a secret key. If Never Expires is checked, then the subkey will never expire. Otherwise, the date shown will be the expiration date.
sect4.note: Changing the expiration date requires a .

sect4.title: Revoke Subkey
sect4.para: The Revoke button will only be shown if the has not been revoked and has a secret key. Clicking Revoke will show the Dialog for the subkey.

sect4.title: Delete Subkey
sect4.para: If the key has a secret key, then you can a subkey by clicking on the Delete button.

sect3.title: Change Passphrase
sect3.para: If the key has a secret key, you can change the key's passphrase by selecting EditChange Passphrase. The first time the Dialog appears is for entering the current passphrase. The second time is for the new passphrase.

sect3.title: Add User ID
sect3.para: If the key has a secret key, you can select EditAdd User ID to add a new User ID. You must then enter the following:

listitem.para: Your full name, which must be at least 5 characters long,
a valid email address,
and an optional comment describing the key

sect3.note: Adding a User ID requires a .

sect3.title: Add Subkey
sect3.para: If the key has a secret key, you can select EditAdd Subkey to add a new subkey. You must then choose from the following key types:
The available length ranges depend on the type selected. Finally, you must choose an expiration date. It can be a specific date in the future, or Never Expires.

sect2.title: Delete
sect2.para: To delete a key, choose EditDelete or click Delete from the Key Manager or of the key you want to delete. The Delete Key dialog is displayed. Click Yes to delete the key.
sect2.warning: This will permanently delete the selected key and cannot be undone.

sect2.title: Revoke
sect2.para: If the key has a secret key, then it or its subkeys can be revoked. Revocation requires one of the following reasons:

listitem.para: No Reason for revoking the key or subkey
The key or subkey has been Compromised
The key or subkey has been replaced.
The key or subkey is no longer used.

sect2.para: and an optional Description of the revocation.

sect2.title: Passphrase
sect2.para:
This dialog is displayed when a passphrase must be entered, usually to unlock a secret key.
Passphrase Dialog
The key for which the passphrase is needed is shown above the entry.

sect2.title: Signatures
sect2.para:
This dialog shows information about a verified signature.
Signature Dialog
Status
The status of the signature, usually Good.
Created
Creation date of the signature.
Signer
User ID of the signing key.
Key ID
Key ID of the signing key.

sect2.title: Recipients
sect2.para:
Use this dialog to select multiple recipients. Currently this used for exporting keys and encrypting data.
Recipients Dialog
The following information is shown for each key:
Name
Key ID
Validity
sect2.caution: Encryption requires that keys are at least Fully Valid.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para:
To show the preferences, choose SettingsPreferences from any window with a menubar. The Preferences dialog is displayed.
Preferences Dialog

sect2.title: Ascii Armor
sect2.para: Checking Ascii Armor will ensure that data is encoded as ASCII text instead of binary. This is necessary for the and part of functionality.

sect2.title: Text Mode
sect2.para: Checking Text Mode will enable text mode.

sect2.title: Default Signing Key
sect2.para: This option menu allows you to choose the default signing key for sign operations. The only keys shown are those that have a secret key and can sign.

glossary.title: Glossary of Terms
glossary.para: Glossary of terms used in &app; and this manual, which may be unfamiliar to those new to encryption.

glossdiv.title: Keys
glossdiv.para: This section describes keys and their various attributes.

glossdef.para: A DSA key can be a primary key, as well as a subkey. It is the default primary key for newly created keys. A DSA key provides signing capabilities. The length ranges from 768 to 1024.
An ElGamal key can only be a subkey. It is the default subkey for newly created keys. An ElGamal subkey provides encryption capabilities. The length ranges from 768 to 4096.
Every key and subkey has an expiration date. For most keys, this date is never. If the key does expire, then it is no longer valid and must be replaced.
The fingerprint is a unique identifier for a key. It is used to verify the identity of the key.
A key is an entity that has the following elements:
A key can also refer to the primary key, or master key. This key that can be signed by others, and any changes affect the entire key.
Every key contains the following attributes:

listitem.para: Key ID
Creation date

glossdef.para: Except for a DSA key, the maximum key length is 4096. For length ranges, see the specific key type.
A key ring is a collection of keys. The keys can be your personal keys and/or other's public keys.

A key signature shows that the signer has validated that key. To verify a key signature, one must have the signed key and the signing key in the key ring. Key signatures are used in calculating a key's validity.
A key's type refers to the algorithm of the key.

Owner trust is a measure of how much you trusts another's key signatures. You may have validated someone's key by signing it, but you do not necessarily trust their judgement in signing other keys. Owner trust is a personal setting kept local to your key ring and cannot be exported. Trust is used in calculating a key's validity. There are currently 5 available trust levels:

listitem.para: This is the highest trust level available. It is reserved for your personal keys, which you trust implicitly. Do not give this level of trust to other keys unless you really know what you are doing.
The owner really knows what they are doing and you trust them enough that their signature is as good as your own.
You trust the owner to properly sign keys, but do not rely on their signature alone.
You do not trust the owner at all.
You are unsure of how much to trust the owner. Imported keys that are not your own are given this trust level by default.

glossdef.para: The public part of a key is shared with others. Depending on the key's type, others can use it to encrypt data to the key's owner and/or verify signatures made by the key's owner.
A RSA key can be a primary key or a subkey. As a primary key, it provides signing capbilities. As a subkey, it can provide signing or encryption capabilities. The length ranges from 1024 to 4096.

The secret part of a key must be kept secure. It is usually protected with a passphrase. Depending on its type, the secret part of a key can be used to decrypt data that has been encrypted with the public key and/or sign data so that it can be verified with the public key.

A subkey provides additional functionality for a key. Generally, the subkey is an ElGamal subkey, which allows others to encrypt to you. Subkeys can be revoked and deleted. Keys can have multiple subkeys.
A user ID has the following elements:

listitem.para: Real Name
Email Address
Optional Comment

glossdef.para: Keys can have multiple user IDs for use in different contexts.
Key validity uses a web of trust model. A key is valid if:

listitem.para: you have signed it personally,
it has been signed by one fully trusted key, or
it has been signed by three marginally trusted keys

glossdef.para: and the path of signed keys leading back from the key is five steps or shorter. The following validity levels are possible:

listitem.para: The key is most likely yours and is fully valid.
The key is not yours, but either you have signed it, someone you trust has signed it, or enough people you marginally trust have signed it.
The key does not have enough marginally trusted signatures and does not have a high enough trust level.
The key has unknown trust and untrusted signatures.

glossdef.para: For examples of the web of trust and key validity, see the Gnu Privacy Handbook.
